comments.text:
+TheBeardedwierdo  *:* *"If you don't think geneology (ancestry) affects 
your gene pool even culturally you have no clue what you are tlaking 
about."*
I never made that statement, so in a sense, you *literally* don't have any 
clue what I am talking about, but to be fair I too am wondering wtf you are 
talking about. 

In any case, here are some basic links on cladistics, haplogroups, 
genetics, race, and the general scientific consensus on the biology of race.

*Cladistics:* *"an approach to biological classification in which organisms 
are grouped together based on whether or not they have one or more shared 
unique characteristics that come from the group's last common ancestor and 
are not present in more distant ancestors."*
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cladistics

*Haplogroups:* *"...a haplogroup (from the Greek: ἁπλούς, haploûs, 
"onefold, single, simple") is a group of similar haplotypes that share a 
common ancestor having the same single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) 
mutation in all haplotypes."*
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haplogroup

*Race in humans:* *"Race is a social concept used to categorize humans into 
large and distinct populations or groups by anatomical, cultural, ethnic, 
genetic, geographical, historical, linguistic, religious, and/or social 
affiliation...."* 
*"Social conceptions and groupings of races vary over time, involving folk 
taxonomies that define essential types of individuals based on perceived 
traits. Scientists consider biological essentialism obsolete..."*
*"Even though there is a broad scientific agreement that essentialist and 
typological conceptualizations of race are untenable, scientists around the 
world continue to conceptualize race in widely differing ways, some of 
which have essentialist implications."* 
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Race_%28human_classification%29

What you are describing is "scientific racism," which is a pseudoscience in 
the same class as astrology and homeopathy.
*Scientific Racism:* *"...is the use of scientific techniques and 
hypotheses to support or justify the belief in racism, racial inferiority, 
or racial superiority, or alternatively the practice of classifying 
individuals of different phenotypes into discrete races. According to the 
United Nations convention, superiority based on racial differentiation is 
scientifically false, morally condemnable, socially unjust and dangerous, 
and there is no justification for racial discrimination, in theory or in 
practice, anywhere."*
*"...scientific racism is sometimes labeled as a pseudoscience."*
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Scientific_racism

comments.text:
It's a manifestation of our hunter-gatherer *tribalism* instinct.  Our 
ancestors lived in a loosely affiliate group of a few dozen people who 
cooperated and shared resources, but no group was ever truly "alone".  The 
instinctual ability to recognize the appearance of members from another 
competing group, afforded that individual greater chances at survival.  
Further reinforcing this effect, this instinct was typically coupled with a 
tendency to trust other members of one's group more than is necessarily 
deserved.  This is the same distrust of outsiders and excessive trust of 
"insiders" (group members) that results in racism and xenophobia, as well 
as a sort of cognitive blindness of suspicious and sketchy members within 
the group.
Also, look up "Dunbar's Number" in order to see how innately difficult it 
is to avoid tribalism tendencies.

comments.text:
+84Doomtrain "If those opinions lead you to attribute what you view as a 
negative thing to all black people or even all of black culture then you 
are being racist."

ok, and by now you've understood that i'm not attributing any 
characteristic to all black people or to any particular black individual; 
rather i'm saying that cultural groups in general have cultural traits etc, 
including black people.

i take it you accept that i am free to have 'a poor view of black culture 
because i don't like it, get it or what have you'. this was the whole point 
i was arguing from the very beginning.

note that just because i say that i am free to have whatever opinion i like 
of black people generally, it does not even follow that i have a low 
opinion of black people. i just want to establish that i am actually free 
to downright despise them if in fact i do; and that i can express that 
valuation openly.

"attacks that you view as perfectly acceptable cease to be acceptable when 
they are launched at a person specifically because they are black, white 
etc"

a proposition is either true or false. if an openly avowed racist says 
something about black people which is true, the fact that he is racist is 
irrelevant. to bring his motivation into it is to change the subject. the 
subject was not his political beliefs, but the truth about black people 
that he brought up. if the proposition is true, what would it mean for it 
to be "unacceptable"? how can any proposition be acceptable or unacceptable 
apart from its truth or falsehood? you cannot object to a true proposition 
on ideological grounds, any more than you can make "acceptable" a false 
proposition on ideological grounds. the only thing that counts about 
proposition is their truth or falsehood; what you think of them politically 
is downright insignificant.

"You think I give a shit what you believe?"

yes. evidently you do.

"Of course races exist"

they don't; race is a nineteenth century pseudo-concept. we are one 
species, within which there is a continuum of genetic difference. there is 
no meaningful place to divide humans up by 'race'.

i'm pleased to find you accept that black culture exists, as well as 
acknowledging my freedom to dislike it. again: that has been exactly what 
i've been asserting all along.

"At the end of the day no one does something just because they are black 
,white etc. they do it for more personal and individual reasons. To assume 
a reaction involving values, attitudes, traditions or culture based on skin 
color is making an assumption with no proof that the individual will act or 
react a certain way due solely to the fact that they are black."

we dont disagree about this. i've repeated again and again that i'm not 
attributing any characteristic to any individual; and you've accepted that 
there is such a thing as black culture, meaning that there are cultural 
properties pertaining to black people.

"My argument is that even if something is more popular in black communities 
that you can't assume that all black people do it. That is the difference 
you are not seeing"

Jesus, i thought you'd understood this point, i've repeated it so many 
times. once more: i am not attributing any characteristic to 'all black 
people', or to any particular black individual; i am saying that cultural 
groups, including black people, have group traits. i'm actually amazed 
you're still struggling with this; i pointed out that you're confusing 
general and universal propositions many posts ago!

you accuse me of "giving credence to the notion that it should be ok to not 
like black people because you don't like aspects of black culture."

where's black culture without black people?

i think there's a misunderstanding here based on the ambiguity of the term 
"black people". it can mean either '(more than one) specific black 
individuals'; or 'black people considered generally as an ethnic group'; or 
'all black individuals'. since i have repeated so often that i'm not 
referring to either individuals or all black people, you should have been 
able to infer that it was the second meaning i had in mind.

"I tried to make it very simple for you and reduce this to one single 
question: Does a person have a right to be a racist"

i really think you're misusing the word 'racist', as i've already 
explained. nonetheless, we're really arguing past one another at this 
point. i have never argued in defence of positive discrimination in 
society, which seems to be what you're concerned with; i'm just not 
interested in that discussion. all i want to establish is my freedom to 
subjectively value various cultural groups as i see fit, and to express 
those valuations openly without being condemned in ideological terms liike 
'racist'.

generally, however, i'm gratified that you seem to have accepted what i was 
concerned to establish.
comments.author: awwitshorace

comments.text:
+awwitshorace
""If he hates them because he hates their culture then that is racist as 
culture is a part of racial identity."

That's a dreadful argument. you're saying i can't have a low opinion of 
black culture because black people identify with it?"

No you are reading it incorrectly. If you are holding a poor view of black 
culture because you don't like it, get it, or what have you that is one 
thing. If those opinions lead you to attribute what you view as a negative 
thing to all black people or even all of black culture then you are being 
racist. I can't expect you to read my mind for what something was supposed 
to mean so I am clearing it up here.

Now lets address your definition of Racism. Those attacks that you view as 
perfectly acceptable cease to be acceptable when they are launched at a

You think I give a shit what you believe? You can choose not to believe in

associated with certain races exist as well.

"I said "we advert to general facts about social groups because they 
evidently and obviously exist"; you replied "no they don't". Do you 
seriously think that there is no such thing as black culture? that black 
people as a group don't have distinct values, attitudes, traditions, 
culture? that doesn't seem very plausible."

There is a massive difference between saying that black culture exists and 
simultaneously using the excuse "because he is black" as an explanation of 
actions of an individual. That was what Taffe was doing in the clips.

Also you conveniently over looked my statement after "No they don't" where 
I explained as much. If you are going to cherry pick my statements at least 
have the decency to get the full context of the argument.

At the end of the day no one does something just because they are black 
,white etc. they do it for more personal and individual reasons. To assume 
a reaction involving values, attitudes, traditions or culture based on skin 
color is making an assumption with no proof that the individual will act or 
react a certain way due solely to the fact that they are black.

My argument is that even if something is more popular in black communities 
that you can't assume that all black people do it. That is the difference 
you are not seeing.

"you keep talking about people being individuals, which obviously i agree 
with; i've been arguing all along about general cultural characteristics 
pertaining to groups. if you seriously don't believe those exist, there's 
nothing more i can say; but i think that's an untenable position."

You can't have your cake and eat it to. You cannot state that you agree 
that all people are individuals and should be evaluated as such while at 
the same time giving credence to the notion that it should be ok to not 
like black people because you don't like aspects of black culture. 

I tried to make it very simple for you and reduce this to one single 
question: Does a person have a right to be a racist if they choose to do 
so. And if they do have that right then how can they express that in social 
or public sectors. I.E. Refusals of service or employment on racial grounds.

I argue that you have a right to choose to be a racist and in which case 
society should choose to ostracize and belittle you. But we have laws on 
the books in this country that prohibit such discrimination when it is 
acted upon in both the public and private sector. Because if and when we 
didn't have such laws it caused major problems for the black community.  
Problems that are still felt today and still have an impact on their lives 
in a very personal way.

comments.text:
"i am not denying any of the 'truth or history of race relations'. I'm 
saying that none of it exempts black people in general from being disliked 
or criticised; i'm saying i have every right to have a low opinion of black 
culture, and of any cultural characteristic black people prominently 
exhibit.

so have you understood the difference between general and universal 
propositins now? i have never said anything about 'all' black people; nor 
have i said anything about any black individual; i have been talking about 
general cultural characteristics, from the very beginning of this 
discussion. every cultural group has them, including black people; i am 
free to dislike those which black culture exhibits."

This whole debate originated with you asking why this asshole did not have 
a right to hate black people if he wanted to. I would not call it a "right" 
but in a way no one can prevent him from choosing to be a racist piece of 
trash if he so chooses. I used "Choose" in that sentence twice because that 
is key to understanding to two sides of this argument. One side is choosing 
to hate the other side for one of two reasons, either he hates them for 
being black, or he hates them for having characteristics that he prescribes 
as being black characteristics. In either case he is wrong for the 
following reasons:

If he hates them just because they are black then he is racist, by 
definition.

If he hates them because he hates their culture then that is racist as 
culture is a part of racial identity.

If he hates them because he hates uniquely "black" traits or 
characteristics then that makes him racist because he is using his 
definition of a "black trait" to project further traits and fears. In this 
final example it makes him short sited as he is attributing his hate to a 
trait or characteristic that may not even be present in that individual 
person.

At the end of the day the entire argument still comes back to his right to 
be a racist. If he can have that right then I get to have the right to hate 
him and all racists for their choices.

And that is what makes me better than them. Racists hate people for things 
that those people cannot change or choose to do differently while I hate 
racists for the specific choices they have made, namely the choice to be 
racist. That is how it is ok to hate a person for their personal choices 
versus things that individuals have no control over. This seems like the 
point you have been trying to make the entire time, a justifiable right to 
not like someone.


"you bring up the incarceration rate, and you mention targeting by police. 
i have no doubt that goes on; indeed, i have no doubt that there is 
discrimination and bias all the way up the judicial system; yet it is 
obvious that is not the whole story behind the higher incarceration rate. 
i'm sure you don't think that most incarcerated black people are 
unimplicated in criminality."

No they are not all completely innocent targets of a racist system but data 
shows that black people are no more likely to commit crimes than people of 
any other race however they do face punishments for those crimes at a much 
higher percentage. Blacks use drugs for instance at the same percentage as 
the population at large yet if you are black and use drugs you are more 
likely to have a run in with the police than a white person. Look at New 
York's stop and frisk policies before those were revoked and how much that 
targeted young black men more than any other group.

"your question about the statistical threshold is the first time you've 
said anything relelvant and engaged, rather than emotional and indignant. 
sociological statisticians deal with these questions day in, day out, with 
agreed thresholds of statistical significance."

Why does every person defending a selfish or poor aspect of society always 
accuse the other side of arguing from emotion lol? This happens constantly 
in you tube comments. I listed several examples during this back and fourth 
and if anyone keeps reiterating that they are still correct in spite of 
arguments to the contrary with no actual proof to back up your statements 
and claims it has been you.

"in your last paragraph you say that making generalisations accomplishes no 
purpose; but we assert general propositions about groups because we cannot 
describe social reality without doing so!"

But you absolutely can. A person should construct their world view from the 
litany of life experiences they go through and people they meet. Ideally 
you will meet people of various cultures and customs and temperaments and 
use that knowledge to be a more open minded and accepting person. Not 
everyone goes through that social maturation and education though. You 
sculpt your Some fervently object to that maturation (racists) and actively 
fight against it and for preserving something they view as unique or 
superior from their group.

"we advert to general facts about social groups because they evidently and 
obviously exist! get off your high horse and look at reality!"

No they don't. People are individuals with their own traits, experiences 
and likes and dislikes.

Take for instance a scenario where you every person you know has watched 
the same TV Show. Can you from that information automatically assume that 
any new person you have met have also seen that show? Of course not.

But with race or cultural issues it is far more serious and can have far 
larger repercussions on those people you meet.  If you are an employer that 
believes that black people are lazy then you will not hire any for your 
company. You are letting your incorrect assumptions affect the lives of 
other people for reasons they cannot change or affect.That is wrong, end of 
story.

top_comment.text:
Two contributing factors. Mr Dunn's lack of respect for the lives of the 
young men and the young men's lack of respect for their elders. I have had 
arguments with my elders and I usually say something about respect for my 
elders, it throws them off, but I mean it and it helps to lead to a 
resolution. There is an epidemic of a lack of respect for elders in today's 
society and it may be a contributing factor in these incidents.
Dunn was wrong as was Zimmerman, but if a grown up asks or even tells you 
to turn your music down, then it probably was too loud and kids should 
never fathom raising their hands to an adult unless the adult is trying to 
put their hands on them first. The Zimmerman issue is a little more 
complicated, but the music thing is stupid, just turn the music down and 
then blast it again once you start driving off. I just think that situation 
was totally avoidable. ﻿
top_comment.author: Cobalt Cr

comments.text:
I placed plus one on your comments because I appreciate a heartfelt 
dialogue. Believe me the bottom line is I am tired of seeing the people of 
my community getting gunned down by these stand your ground folks. I do 
wonder what would happen if one of us stood our ground? I know about the 
sista in Florida, which is a jacked up state imo, for black folks. She got 
jail time without even killing anybody. As I said earlier, I was merely 
speculating if the situation could have been alleviated by a little 
respect, but yes racism is what it is and it sucks. Yet those kids could 
have been bigger men then Dunn in that situation which could have made him 
really look more like an ass AND the young man might still be alive.
 I failed to mention not letting crazy a-holes get their hands on guns too. 
That wasn't my point to list everything. I was combining two trends, the 
blazing lack of respect and failure to realize that these racist folks will 
shoot your azz with the trend of racist folks who will shoot your azz 
without giving it a thought.
Maybe I am saying don't give them another reason because being black and 
young is probably already more than enough.

comments.text:

harm at all. I was merely speculating if that old concept of respect for 
elders would have possibly alleviated the situations. It may not have

I am also concerned about the lack of respect for elders when we see trends 
like the knock out game too. That is a case of young folks knocking the
